Award.AwardTitle: DIP: Collaborative Research: Impact of Adaptive Interventions on Student Affect, Performance, and Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
A major factor influencing learning is students' emotions and their general affective state. Given the pivotal role that affect plays in learning activities it is not surprising that there has been a good deal of interest in developing affect-aware technologies. The overwhelming majority of this work, however, has focused on modeling affect, that is designing computational models capable of inferring how students are feeling while interacting with an Intelligent Tutoring System (ITS). While modeling of affect is a critical first step in providing adaptive support tailored to students' affective needs, very little work exists on systematically exploring the impact of affective interventions on students' performance, learning, affect and attitudes, i.e., how to respond to students' emotions such as frustration, anxiety, boredom, and hopelessness as they arise. The research fills this gap by analyzing the value of tailoring different types of interventions to negative affective states for individual students and groups of students.

The project has two main goals. First, it addresses how to respond to negative student emotion such as frustration, anxiety, boredom in computer-based learning environments through a variety of interventions. Some correspond to specially-designed digital characters, integrated into the learning environment, which are intended to act like students' learning companions. These agents support students through non-verbal behaviors such as having the characters express empathy in response to student frustration, or by messages targeting students' cognitive and meta-cognitive skills, as well as motivation and affect. Other interventions involve supporting collaboration between students to mitigate negative emotional states when detected. The impact of these interventions are investigated through a series of eight experiments with a total of 800 students. These experiments help to unveil general prescriptive principles to address student affect.

The second goal accomplished by this research is that the experiments provide valuable data to continue to extend and validate existing models of emotion. Specifically, the project triangulates and integrates a complex space of partially overlapping models and constructs of affect in learning (i.e. emotions, attitudes, incoming moods, motivation, engaged use or misuse of software). The project refines several well-established models, in particular the control-value theory of emotions to provide a more stable theoretical framework for the field of emotions in educational software.

This research is unique and ground breaking, as few researchers have targeted students' emotion in classrooms, gathered fine grained data on emotions during learning, or assessed the impact of specific affective treatments on a moment-to-moment basis. Students using the tutoring systems have already shown statistically significant gains and learning outcomes, as well as increased positive affect and attitudes. The new affective interventions will greatly increase the broad impact of these systems.

This project is developing: (1) prescriptive principles about how to respond to student affect; (2) new understanding about the impact of cognitive, affective, and meta-cognitive interventions on emotions and learning; (3) new understanding about individual differences in learning, unveiling the extent to which emotion, cognitive abilities, and gender impact learning; (4) instruction that is sensitive to individual differences; and (5) refined theories of student emotion.

This research is also: (1) increasing participation in mathematics of underrepresented populations (women and minorities) who often avoid STEM careers; (2) creating broad access to web-based technologies that help to engage more students by addressing their affective and social needs; and (3) addressing the one-size-fits-all approach to education, by responding to individual student needs with alternative representations of content and pathways through which material is presented.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Key Findings of the Project:

1. Empathic messages delivered by characters, which are spoken messages that responded to students’ recent emotions (also written in dialog bubbles) have resulted in improved student interaction with the math tutoring system and the overall learning experience, compared to controls. Growth Mindset messages follow next with some positive impact on in­ tutor performance but its overall effect in the short­term is questionable. Interestingly, the traditional Success/Failure messages (try again, good job!, ‘wrong, shall we work it out on paper?’) appear generally harmful to students: reducing learning orientation, decreasing students’ feelings of confidence/hope, and making students more careless during the learning experience. We conclude that affective messages delivered by characters in online tutoring environments are a very important medium for building student­tutor rapport in a virtual environment, powerful signals that influence perceptions of students themselves as learners, as well as perceptions of the domain being taught. We have reported significant results that support the use of empathy to improve student affect and attitudes. We plan to continue studying the long­term effect of these messages, as well as the impact of their frequency and variety. Diverse demographics need to be studied, to evaluate the generalizability of these results.

2. Collaborative Learning interventions that add social value (by working with a specific neighboring partner, as invited by MathSpring) to the tutoring experience yielded positive results on affect ­­in particular, student interest. An analysis revealed that affective predisposition of student interest in math problem solving improved at posttest time as students interacted with more collaborative experiences, measured in a variety of ways (collaborations completed, on my screen, on partner’s screen, etc.). Later, the Markov Chain analysis showed that the immediate impact of collaborating with a partner, or being invited to collaborate with a partner, implies changes towards higher levels of interest in near future self­ reports some minutes later, when compared to individual mode. On the other hand, this same analysis suggested increased frustration after collaborating. The data has shown evidence that such frustration may be generated to two factors: to the fact that there is a preference for collaboration, and that some students do not like the idea of collaborating with other students, for a variety of reasons; the fact that students who collaborated from the neighboring computer (i.e., did not host the collaboration on their screen) did not have a choice to refuse that collaboration; and last, the fact that the initiating student had to wait for a partner to be available, sometimes for too long. We could potentially eliminate the increases in frustration by giving more choices to refuse collaboration, and allowing students to set their preferences for collaboration at different moments during the tutoring session.

3. A control­ oriented intervention that allows students to self­reflect on their performance and their effort ( Student Progress Page) provided mixed results. It improved student interest in near transfer measures ­­in the following emotion self­report. It also was the only intervention that showed indicators of improved performance and learning, as students using the Student Progress Page more often encountered harder math problems and solved more of these problems correctly on the first attempt.

Concerning our findings, the following are general conclusions that make an impact on the base of knowledge on how people learn with digital learning technologies:

a) Characters within learning environments such as intelligent tutoring systems are, either explicitly or implicitly, powerful transmitters of affective messages, with repercussions shown in students’ affective states, affective predispositions, engagement with the learning environment, and importantly, also an impact on mathematics learning. Growth Mindset and Empathic messages can impact students emotions.

b) Social Collaborative experiences with other students for shared problem solving can enhance student interest in math problem solving.

c) Student progress pages that encourage students to reflect on their past performance (a metacognitive perspective) as well as games need to be further thought out in order to impact student emotions. Initial findings suggest that their impact is simply too weak at improving true interest and excitement towards problem solving.

The following are general conclusions that make an impact on research methods regarding digital learning technologies:

a) We are starting to find that current methods for affect detection fall short to help to understand what students might need to have a better affective experience. Richer qualitative methods that have the students further explain "what is going on" in their heads, and perceptions of what they might need, are starting to be implemented in response to this.

b) Research methods for analyzing the impact of interventions need to take into account a variety of other factors that might influence student emotion, that richly describe the student and the context, and that may moderate and influence student affective and cognitive states, for a fair comparison between experimental and control groups.
